name: Cotton (conventional)
description: Conventional cotton grown using typical farming practices. High water usage; moderate CO2.
notes: High water footprint; lower recyclability compared to synthetics.

name: Organic Cotton
description: Cotton grown with organic farming methods. Lower chemical inputs.
notes: Better for soil & biodiversity; slightly lower yields.

name: Recycled Cotton
description: Cotton produced from textile waste. Lower water & CO2 footprints.
notes: Quality depends on feedstock; blending often required.

name: Polyester (virgin)
description: Synthetic fiber made from fossil fuels. High CO2 and energy consumption.
notes: Durable and cheap; microplastics and fossil origin are concerns.

name: Recycled Polyester (rPET)
description: Polyester made from recycled PET bottles. Much lower CO2 than virgin polyester.
notes: Good circular potential; still releases microfibers.

name: Hemp
description: Low-input fiber with strong durability and lower environmental impacts.
notes: Excellent for sustainable textiles where legal/processing supply exists.

name: Linen (Flax)
description: Fiber from flax plant; low water and energy inputs per kg.
notes: Great biodegradability and durability; often premium price.

name: Wool
description: Animal fiber with high CO2 due to livestock emissions, but very durable and warm.
notes: Consider animal welfare and land-use impacts.

name: Tencel (Lyocell)
description: Regenerated cellulose fiber with relatively low impacts and closed-loop production.
notes: Good substitution for viscose with better processing footprint.

name: Bamboo Viscose
description: Viscose regenerated from bamboo; processing varies and impacts can be high.
notes: Look for closed-loop process claims (e.g., Lenzing).

name: Nylon (virgin)
description: Energy intensive synthetic fiber with high CO2 and energy footprints.
notes: Often used where high strength/elasticity is required.

name: Recycled Nylon
description: Nylon produced from post-consumer/industrial waste. Lower CO2 vs virgin.
